questions.text: A 21-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of yellowing of his eyes. He has also noticed a decrease in his exercise capacity and gets quickly exhausted after minor physical activity. Examination shows scleral icterus and pale mucous membranes. He has splenomegaly. His hemoglobin concentration is 7.9 mg/dL, leukocyte count 8500/mm³ and platelet count is 1.8 lakhs/mm3. Direct antiglobulin and heterophile antibody tests are positive. Which of the following additional laboratory findings are most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decreased haptoglobin levels

 

  • The patient has scleral icterus, anemia, splenomegaly, and positive direct antiglobulin (Coombs) and heterophile antibody tests. This indicates autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) triggered by infectious mononucleosis (Epstein-Barr virus).
  • In hemolytic anemia, haptoglobin binds free hemoglobin released from destroyed red blood cells, leading to decreased serum haptoglobin levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased reticulocyte count: Reticulocyte count would be increased, not decreased, due to compensatory bone marrow response.

 

Option C. Decreased mean corpuscular volume: Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) is typically normal or slightly increased in hemolytic anemia.

 

Option D. Increased direct to total bilirubin ratio: Direct to total bilirubin ratio is usually decreased because hemolysis increases indirect (unconjugated) bilirubin.

questions.text: A 55-year-old chronic smoker presents with weight loss, hemoptysis and TTF-1 positivity. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenocarcinoma

 

TTF-1 (thyroid transcription factor-1) positivity is a marker commonly associated with lung adenocarcinoma and small cell carcinoma but is most classically used to identify adenocarcinoma in lung cancers. Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of lung cancer in smokers and non-smokers alike and often presents with weight loss and hemoptysis.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma: Usually TTF-1 negative; more commonly shows keratinization and intercellular bridges.

 

Option B. Small cell carcinoma: May be TTF-1 positive but typically presents with rapid progression and different histopathology.

 

Option D. Large cell carcinoma: Typically lacks TTF-1 expression and has a less differentiated histology.

questions.text: The resting membrane potential(RMP) of the nerve is - 70mV. Increased permeability of which ion is responsible for the RMP?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Potassium

 

The resting membrane potential (RMP ≈ –70 mV) is mainly determined by the high permeability of the neuronal membrane to potassium (K⁺) at rest.

 

Potassium leak channels allow K⁺ to diffuse out of the cell (down its concentration gradient), leaving behind negatively charged proteins, which stabilizes the negative RMP.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Calcium: Intracellular calcium concentration is very low, but calcium channels are closed at rest; negligible role in RMP.
 

Option B. Sodium: Some Na⁺ leaks in, but at rest the membrane is much less permeable to Na⁺ compared to K⁺.
 

Option D. Chloride: Helps in inhibitory signaling, but does not primarily set the RMP.

questions.text: A patient came with hypoxemia and a normal alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient. What can be the cause? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypoventilation

 

Hypoxemia with a normal alveolar-arterial (A-a) oxygen gradient typically points to specific causes where the alveolar oxygen (PAO2) and arterial oxygen (PaO2) levels remain proportionate. In this scenario, the primary causes are hypoventilation and situations involving low inspired oxygen tension (low FiO2).

 

Hypoventilation: This condition leads to hypoxemia due to inadequate ventilation. When ventilation is insufficient, the amount of oxygen entering the alveoli drops, leading to a corresponding decrease in the amount of oxygen diffusing into the blood, resulting in hypoxemia. However, because the underlying issue is with ventilation and not with oxygen diffusion or blood flow, the A-a gradient remains normal.

 

Low FiO2 or Low Barometric Pressure: This can occur in scenarios such as high altitude where the barometric pressure is low, leading to reduced oxygen availability in the air. However, these situations were not explicitly listed among the answer choices.

 

According to the reference paragraph, other conditions like ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) mismatch, diffusion limitation, and alveolar membrane damage, cause an increased A-a gradient due to impaired oxygen transfer across the alveolar membrane or mismatched ventilation and perfusion in the lungs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right to left shunt: This condition causes hypoxemia due to blood bypassing the lungs and not getting oxygenated. It leads to an increased A-a gradient because the oxygen content of the arterial blood is significantly lower compared to the alveolar oxygen level.

 

Option B. Ventilation/Perfusion mismatch: This condition results from areas of the lung receiving oxygen but not perfused with blood or areas perfused with blood but not receiving oxygen. It causes an increased A-a gradient due to ineffective oxygen transfer to the blood.

 

Option D. Alveolar membrane damage: This results in impaired oxygen diffusion across the alveolar-capillary membrane, leading to an increased A-a gradient as oxygen transfer from alveoli to blood is hindered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypoventilation is a primary cause of hypoxemia with a normal alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a hemostatic agent? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Boric acid

 

Boric acid is not a hemostatic agent. Boric acid is commonly used as an antiseptic, insecticide, and in various industrial applications, but it does not possess properties that would promote blood coagulation or control bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zeolite and Option D. Kaolin are microporous aluminosilicate minerals with large surface areas, having high hygroscopicity and excellent hemostatic performance. Zeolite absorbs blood and the releases Ca2+ into the blood and to activate the intrinsic path of coagulation cascade.

 

Option B. Chitosan: Chitosan is a biopolymer derived from chitin, which is found in the shells of crustaceans. Chitosan and its derivatives are known to accelerate the hemostasis process by promoting platelet adhesion and activation. This helps in forming a stable clot more quickly, which is particularly useful in controlling external bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Boric acid is not a hemostatic agent. Hemostatic agents like Zeolite, Chitosan, and Kaolin work by activating the coagulation pathways to control bleeding.

questions.text: Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocyte to the plasma by binding to? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ferroportin

 

Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocyte to plasma by binding to ferroportin.

 

Iron absorption is regulated by hepcidin, a small circulating peptide that is synthesized and released from the liver in response to increases in intrahepatic iron levels.

 

Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocyte to plasma by binding to ferriportin and causing it to be endocytosed and degraded. As a result, as hepcidin levels rise, iron becomes trapped within duodenal cells in the form of mucosal ferritin and is lost as these cells are sloughed. Thus, when the body is replete with iron, high hepcidin levels inhibit its absorption into the blood.

 

Conversely, with low body stores of iron, hepcidin synthesis falls and this in turn facilitates iron absorption. By inhibiting ferriportin, hepcidin not only reduces iron uptake from enterocytes but also suppresses iron release from macrophages, which are an important source of the iron that is used by erythroid precursors to make hemoglobin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Transferrin: Transferrin is a plasma protein that binds iron in the blood and transports it to various tissues, particularly the bone marrow for erythropoiesis. Hepcidin does not bind to transferrin; instead, it regulates iron export through ferroportin.

 

Option C. Divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1): DMT1 is involved in the uptake of iron (in its ferrous form) from the lumen of the intestine into enterocytes. Hepcidin does not interact with DMT1; its regulatory effect occurs after iron has been absorbed into enterocytes, at the point of iron export into the bloodstream via ferroportin.

 

Option D. Ferritin: Ferritin is the intracellular protein that stores iron in a soluble and non-toxic form. Hepcidin does not bind to ferritin directly. However, by reducing the expression of ferroportin, hepcidin indirectly increases the storage of iron within cells in the form of ferritin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepcidin regulates iron homeostasis by binding to ferroportin, leading to its degradation, which prevents iron export from enterocytes into the plasma and from macrophages.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg 1231

choices.text: At eight weeks the embryo is bipotent
Wolffian duct develops into epididymis and vas deferens on either side
Mullerian inhibiting substance inhibits mullerian duct
DHT leads to the development of secondary sexual characters and external genitalia

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about male sexual development? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) At eight weeks the embryo is bipotent

 

Explanation:

 

At eight weeks of gestation, the embryo is no longer bipotent. The term "bipotent" refers to the embryo's capability to develop into either male or female structures, which is true up until about the sixth week of development. By the eighth week, sexual differentiation is already underway, with the influence of the SRY gene causing the gonads to differentiate into testes in 46XY embryos. This differentiation results in a shift away from bipotency, making the embryo committed to developing male characteristics.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Wolffian duct develops into epididymis and vas deferens on either side : This statement is true. The Wolffian ducts, under the influence of testosterone, develop into the male reproductive structures including the epididymis and vas deferens.

 

Option C. Mullerian inhibiting substance inhibits Mullerian duct: This statement is true. Mullerian inhibiting substance (MIS), also known as anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH), is produced by Sertoli cells in the testes and inhibits the development of the Mullerian ducts, which would otherwise develop into female reproductive structures such as the uterine tubes and uterus.

 

Option D. DHT leads to the development of secondary sexual characters and external genitalia: This statement is true. Dihydrotestosterone (DHT), a potent metabolite of testosterone, is crucial for the development of male external genitalia and secondary sexual characteristics such as facial hair and a deeper voice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

At eight weeks of gestation, the embryo is no longer bipotent; sexual differentiation has already commenced.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes in with primary amenorrhea and indications of virilization. She displays underdeveloped breasts and pubic hair consistent with prepubertal stages, rated at Tanner stage 2. She has a closed-off vaginal canal and noticeable enlargement of the clitoris. Despite her female sex, her testosterone levels are within the male range. Her genetic makeup is 46XY. What is the likely medical diagnosis in this case? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 5 alpha reductase deficiency

 

Explanation:

 

The given scenario points to a diagnosis of 5 alpha reductase deficiency.

 

5 alpha reductase deficiency causes inability to convert testosterone to DHT.

 

When DHT levels are low, newborns will possess external genitalia with a feminine appearance. These youngsters are commonly brought up as girls until they reach puberty, at which point they begin to display signs of masculinization due to the influence of testosterone. As a result, clitoromegaly becomes evident. The absence of estrogen conversion from testosterone results in limited breast growth. Scanty pubic hair is observed since its growth is contingent on both testosterone and dihydrotestosterone.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complete AIS (Androgen insensitivity syndrome): Defect in androgen receptor resulting in female-appearing genetic male (46, XY); female external genitalia with scant axillary and pubic hair, rudimentary vagina; uterus and fallopian tubes absent due to persistence of anti-Mullerian hormone from testes. Patients develop normal functioning testes. Patient has increased testosterone, estrogen & LH as compared to other sex chromosome disorders.

 

Option C. Swyer syndrome: 46 XY gonadal dysgenesis; Absent secondary sexual characters, but normal female internal and external genitalia. Gonadectomy needs to be done.

 

Option D. 17 alpha hydroxylase deficiency: Leads to reduced formation of corticosteroids, sex hormones and increased mineralocorticoids (causing hypokalemia and hypertension). Patient with XY chromosome presents with atypical genitalia and undescended testes. Patient with XX chromosome lacks secondary sexual development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

5-alpha reductase deficiency causes primary amenorrhea and virilization in genetic females (46XY), resulting in the inability to convert testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT). This leads to female external genitalia at birth and masculinization at puberty, with signs such as clitoromegaly and underdeveloped breasts.

questions.text: An investigator is studying cellular repair mechanisms in various tissues. One of the samples being reviewed is from the anterior horn of the spinal cord of a patient who was involved in a snowboard accident. Pathologic examination of the biopsy specimen shows dispersion of the Nissl bodies, swelling of the neuronal body, and a displacement of the nucleus to the periphery in numerous cells. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the observed findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Central chromatolysis

 

Central chromatolysis is the neuronal cell-body response to axonal injury — features include dispersion of Nissl substance, cellular swelling, and eccentric displacement of the nucleus as the neuron upregulates protein synthesis to support axonal regeneration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neurodegenerative changes: Usually a chronic process with neuronal loss, Lewy bodies, neurofibrillary tangles, etc., not the acute Nissl dispersal and cell swelling seen here.


Option B. Wallerian degeneration: Refers to degeneration of the axon distal to the site of injury, not the characteristic soma changes (Nissl dispersion) described.


Option D. Reactive astrogliosis: Involves proliferation/hypertrophy of astrocytes (GFAP+) after CNS injury, not the neuronal Nissl and nuclear displacement findings.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the OPD due to occasional dull headaches that awaken him from sleep. The patient has no associated neurologic deficits. On physical examination, there are several 3 cm to 5 cm flat, pigmented spots on his trunk. There are also multiple, subcentimeter, soft, fleshy, cutaneous tumors located on his trunk and neck. The predominant cells forming these tumors most likely originated from which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neural crest

 

This patient's findings (multiple cutaneous neurofibromas and café-au-lait spots) are classic for Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). The predominant cells forming neurofibromas (Schwann cells) originate from the neural crest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endoderm:

 

  • Gives rise to epithelial lining of GI tract, respiratory tract, and associated glands.
  • Does not contribute to cutaneous tumors or neural tissue.
  • Unrelated to the pathogenesis of neurofibromas.

 

Option B. Mesoderm:

 

  • Forms muscle, bone, connective tissue, and blood vessels.
  • Not the source of Schwann cells or melanocytes in skin lesions.
  • Provides structural support but not the neural elements here.

 

Option D. Neural tube:

 

  • Gives rise to central nervous system neurons and glial cells.
  • Does not form peripheral nerves or Schwann cells.
  • Involved in CNS but not in cutaneous neurofibromas.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. His blood pressure is 165/92 mm Hg on the left arm and 162/90 mm Hg on the right arm. He reports that he is adherent with his medication and exercise regimen. The physician adds a drug to his antihypertensive medication regimen. This drug increases serum renin, angiotensin I, and angiotensin II levels, and decreases serum aldosterone levels, without affecting bradykinin levels. Which of the following drugs was most likely added to this patient's medication regimen?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Candesartan

 

  • The drug described increases serum renin, angiotensin I, and angiotensin II levels but decreases aldosterone levels without affecting bradykinin.
  • Candesartan is an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB). ARBs block the angiotensin II receptor, leading to decreased aldosterone production.
  • Because they block the receptor but not the production of angiotensin II, levels of renin, angiotensin I, and angiotensin II increase due to feedback.
  • ARBs do not inhibit bradykinin breakdown, so bradykinin levels remain unchanged.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aliskiren: Direct renin inhibitor; lowers renin and downstream angiotensins.

 

Option C. Verapamil: Calcium channel blocker; does not affect renin-angiotensin system.

 

Option D. Lisinopril: ACE inhibitor; increases bradykinin levels by blocking its degradation.

choices.text: It is best tested in the fasting state on day 2 of menstrual cycle

questions.text: All of the following statements about anti-Mullerian hormones are true, except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is best tested in the fasting state on day 2 of menstrual cycle

 

Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) is a glycoprotein secreted by the Sertoli cells in males and the granulosa cells of early antral follicles in females. It serves as a marker of ovarian reserve and is crucial in assessing fertility potential. Here are the reasons why option A is incorrect:

 

  • AMH Testing: Unlike some other hormones, AMH does not require fasting and can be tested at any time during the menstrual cycle. The timing of testing AMH is not restricted to day 2 of the menstrual cycle as with some other reproductive hormone assessments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glycoprotein from granulosa cell of early antral follicle: This is a true statement. AMH is indeed a glycoprotein produced by the granulosa cells of early antral follicles in the ovaries.

 

Option C. Correlates with pregnancy rate of IVF cycles: This is also true. AMH levels correlate with ovarian reserve and can give an indication of the likelihood of a successful IVF cycle. Higher levels generally suggest a better response to ovarian stimulation and thus potentially higher pregnancy rates.

 

Option D. It decreases sensitivity of the pre-antral follicles to FSH: This statement is correct. AMH reduces the sensitivity of pre-antral and small antral follicles to Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH), which is a mechanism to regulate follicle recruitment and maturation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) does not need to be tested in the fasting state or specifically on day 2 of the menstrual cycle.

 

Ref: Page no 76, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: When papain acts on a molecule of immunoglobulin, which of the following are the end products? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 Fc and 2 Fab fragments

 

When papain acts on a molecule of immunoglobulin, the end products are 1 Fc and 2 Fab fragments.

 

If an antibody molecule is digested with papain, cleavage occurs above the disulfide bonds that hold the heavy chains together. This generates 3 separate fragments, two of which are called Fab (fragment antigen binding), and one of which is called Fc (fragment crystallizable).

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

When an immunoglobulin molecule is digested with papain, the end products are 1 Fc fragment and 2 Fab fragments.

questions.text:
What is/are correct statement(s) regarding skeletal muscle? (INICET May 2023)

 

  1. Extracellular calcium entry is important in the skeletal muscle contraction.
  2. Calcium is mainly released from mitochondria.
  3. Calcium is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
  4. Voltage-gated calcium channel on sarcolemma has no role in excitation-contraction coupling.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Only 3

 

The accurate fact concerning skeletal muscle is that the release of calcium occurs from the sarcoplasmic reticulum only.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Extracellular calcium plays a significant role in sustaining cardiac muscle contraction , not in skeletal muscle.

 

2. The sarcoplasmic reticulum is filled with high concentrations of calcium ions stored in its vesicular tubules. Upon the occurrence of an action potential in the neighboring T tubule, these calcium ions are discharged from each vesicle.

 

4. Activation of  voltage-gated calcium channel is essential in excitation-contraction coupling, i.e. it a has important role. Activation of receptor results in the initiation of calcium release from RyR channels, leading to the liberation of calcium ions from the sarcoplasm surrounding the myofibrils, consequently triggering muscle contraction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum is essential for skeletal muscle contraction.

questions.text: The enzyme that is common for both glycolysis and gluconeogenesis is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Phosphoglycerate kinase

 

Phosphoglycerate kinase catalyzes the conversion of 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate to 3-phosphoglycerate, which is a reversible step involved in glycolysis and gluconeogenesis hence it is common for both pathways.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyruvate kinase: Pyruvate kinase is involved only in glycolysis and catalyzes the conversion of phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP) to pyruvate. It is not involved in gluconeogenesis.

 

Option B. Phosphofructokinase: Phosphofructokinase is a key regulatory enzyme in glycolysis, converting fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate. It does not play a role in gluconeogenesis.

 

Option C. Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase: Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase is involved in gluconeogenesis, converting oxaloacetate to phosphoenolpyruvate. It is not involved in glycolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phosphoglycerate kinase is a common enzyme in both glycolysis and gluconeogenesis, catalyzing a reversible reaction that interconverts 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate and 3-phosphoglycerate.

 

Other reversible steps of glycolysis are catalyzed by the following enzymes:

  • Phosphoglycerate mutase
  • Glyceraldehyde phosphate dehydrogenase
  • Triose phosphate isomerase
  • Aldolase
  • Phosphohexose isomerase

questions.text: The phlebotomist needs to collect samples from a patient for various tests. Among the options provided, which sequence of blood collection for testing ensures that the sample remains uncontaminated, considering the additives present in the collection tubes?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Light blue → Red → Lavender → Grey

 

  • Light blue (Citrate tube): Collected first to avoid contamination with clot activators or EDTA that can affect coagulation studies.
  • Red (Plain tube, no anticoagulant): Collected next for serology/chemistry, avoids interference from EDTA or fluoride.
  • Lavender (EDTA tube): Collected later for hematology; prevents EDTA carryover from affecting earlier tests.
  • Grey (Fluoride oxalate tube): Collected last for glucose/lactate estimation, since fluoride inhibits glycolysis and would interfere with other tests if drawn earlier.

questions.text:
A 9-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department due to prolonged epistaxis. The girl says that she picked her nose immediately before the bleeding started. Her parents decided to take her to the emergency department after the epistaxis persisted for 20 minutes despite constant compression.  The patient has had frequent nosebleeds that often last >10 minutes. Laboratory tests are ordered, and results are as follows:

 

Hematocrit: 43%

 

Bleeding time: prolonged

 

Partial thromboplastin time (PTT): prolonged

 

Prothrombin time (PT): normal

 

Thrombin time (TT): normal

 

D-dimer: normal

 

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) von Willebrand disease 

 

  • The patient presents with prolonged bleeding time and prolonged partial thromboplastin time (PTT), but with normal prothrombin time (PT) and normal thrombin time (TT), consistent with a defect in the intrinsic pathway.
  • von Willebrand disease (vWD) is the most common inherited bleeding disorder and causes defective platelet adhesion, leading to prolonged bleeding time.
  • vWD also causes prolonged PTT because von Willebrand factor stabilizes factor VIII; its deficiency decreases factor VIII levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factor XIll deficiency: Factor XIII deficiency causes normal coagulation tests but abnormal wound healing and bleeding.

 

Option B. Hemophilia A: Hemophilia A causes prolonged PTT but normal bleeding time.

 

Option C. Vitamin K deficiency: The normal PT differentiates it from vitamin K deficiency, which prolongs both PT and PTT.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for scrub typhus during pregnancy and otherwise respectively? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Azithromycin, doxycycline

 

The DOC for scrub typhus is Doxycycline, but it cannot be used during pregnancy as it can lead to bone growth abnormality in the newborn. So, in that case, to treat Scrub Typhus in Pregnancy, we use Azithromycin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chloramphenicol, doxycycline: Chloramphenicol is not the first-line treatment for scrub typhus, and doxycycline is indeed used for non-pregnant individuals, but this pair does not cover the correct alternatives during pregnancy.

 

Option B. Doxycycline, doxycycline: This option does not address the contraindication of doxycycline during pregnancy.

 

Option C. Doxycycline, azithromycin: This reverses the correct pair; azithromycin is used during pregnancy, not doxycycline.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The drug of choice for treating scrub typhus in pregnant women is azithromycin, while doxycycline is used for non-pregnant individuals.

questions.text: Identify the disease transmitted by the vector shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zika virus disease

 

The mosquito in the image is Aedes aegypti, also known as the "tiger mosquito" due to the distinctive white stripes on its body and legs. Aedes aegypti is well-known for its "hunchback" posture when feeding and has a flight range of approximately 100 meters, although it may travel farther under certain conditions. This mosquito species primarily breeds in artificial collections of rainwater, such as in discarded tires, bottles, or containers that collect water during the rainy season.

 

Aedes aegypti is the vector responsible for transmitting several viral diseases, including:

 

  • Zika virus disease
  • Dengue fever
  • Chikungunya fever
  • Yellow fever

 

In this case, the correct answer is Zika virus disease, as it is directly associated with this mosquito species.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. JE (Japanese Encephalitis): Japanese Encephalitis is transmitted by the Culex mosquito, specifically Culex tritaeniorhynchus, not by Aedes aegypti.

 

Option C. Malaria: Malaria is transmitted by Anopheles mosquitoes, primarily Anopheles gambiae and Anopheles stephensi in different regions, not by Aedes aegypti.

 

Option D. Lymphatic filariasis: Lymphatic filariasis is transmitted by Culex quinquefasciatus (also known as Culex fatigans) in certain regions, rather than by Aedes aegypti.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Aedes aegypti is the vector responsible for transmitting diseases such as Zika virus, dengue, chikungunya, and yellow fever. It is characterized by white stripes on its body and legs and typically breeds in man-made water collections.

questions.text: A 24-year-old G2 at 28 weeks is brought to the emergency after being found unconscious at home by her mother. She is disoriented on arrival and her BP is 180/110 mmHg and 4 + proteinuria. On arrival at the emergency, she has a tonic-clonic seizure which resolves with MgSO4 administration. Once the patient is stabilized, she undergoes caesarean delivery for fetal distress. Post-partum, the below MRI is done. What is the most likely finding on imaging?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome

 

  • The case is classic for eclampsia: pregnant woman with hypertension, proteinuria, seizures.
  • The MRI shows bilateral symmetrical areas of hyperintensity in the posterior cerebral hemispheres (parieto-occipital regions), most characteristic of PRES.
  • PRES is associated with eclampsia and presents with headache, altered mental status, seizures, and visual disturbances. MRI usually shows vasogenic edema—seen as high signal in posterior regions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subdural hematoma, Option B. Parenchymal hemorrhage, Option C. Subarachnoid hemorrhage: Would show focal or diffuse hyperintensity in different locations, not typically as bilateral posterior edema.

questions.text: The drug of choice for insomnia in blind people is? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tasimelteon

 

Tasimelteon and Ramelteon are melatonin agonists. Tasimelteon is used for the treatment of insomnia in blind persons, whereas Ramelteon is used for the treatment of jet lag and also used for sleep induction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Latanoprostene: Is not relevant to the treatment of insomnia. It is a medication used to reduce intraocular pressure in patients with glaucoma or ocular hypertension.

 

Option B. Zerviate: Is an antihistamine eye drop used for the treatment of ocular itching associated with allergic conjunctivitis, not for insomnia.

 

Option D. Ramelteon: Is also a melatonin receptor agonist used for the treatment of insomnia, specifically for difficulties with sleep onset. It is not specifically indicated for Non-24-Hour Sleep-Wake Disorder in blind individuals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tasimelteon is the drug of choice for treating insomnia in blind individuals due to its effectiveness in regulating the sleep-wake cycle by acting as a melatonin receptor agonist, particularly in those with Non-24-Hour Sleep-Wake Disorder.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man is hospitalized for acute chest pain and undergoes PCI. His serum creatinine is unchanged 3 days post-procedure, but from day 4 slowly rises to a peak of 2.4 mg/dL. Urinalysis demonstrates no proteinuria or red blood cells, and a few granular casts are present. Serum complement is low. Blood counts show eosinophilia.  Which one of the following is likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Atheroembolic disease

 

Atheroembolic renal disease occurs after vascular procedures (like PCI), due to cholesterol crystal embolization. It presents with rising creatinine days after procedure, eosinophilia, low complement, and bland urine sediment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allergic interstitial nephritis: Typically shows fever, rash, eosinophiluria, and WBC casts, not low complement.

 

Option B. CIN: Contrast nephropathy occurs within 24–48 hours, not delayed rise after 3–5 days.

 

Option D. RPGN: Characterized by rapid renal failure, hematuria, RBC casts, not seen here.

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. Physical examination shows nontender cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy. The spleen is palpated 5 cm below the costal margin. Her leukocyte count is 12,000/mm 3 and platelet count is 217,000/mm 3. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Smudge cells

 

  • The patient has painless lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, mild leukocytosis, and normal platelets, a presentation suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL).
  • Peripheral blood smear in CLL characteristically shows smudge cells, which are fragile, broken leukocytes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ringed sideroblasts: Seen in sideroblastic anemia.

 

Option B. Teardrop cells: Associated with myelofibrosis and marrow infiltration.

 

Option D. Rouleaux formation: Seen in multiple myeloma, characterized by stacked red blood cells.

Since then, he has only had a few periods of time when he did not feel that way, but none of these lasted for more than a month. He reports having no problems with appetite, weight, or energy. He does not use illicit drugs or alcohol. Mental status examination shows a depressed mood and constricted affect. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Persistent depressive disorder

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 2-hour history of headache, nausea, blurred vision, and pain in the left eye. She has had similar symptoms in the past. Her vital signs are within normal limits. The left eye is red and is hard on palpation. The left pupil is mid-dilated and nonreactive to light. Administration of which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Epinephrine

questions.text:
Identify the incorrect statements:

questions.solution: Ans. C) 3, 4

questions.text: A 57-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. During the last 6 months, he has had recurring pneumonia after undergoing a surgical operation. He reports that, when food has gone down his windpipe, he has not automatically coughed. Examination shows normal voluntary coughing, but an impaired cough reflex. The nerve responsible for this patient's symptoms is most likely damaged at which of the following anatomical sites?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Piriform recess

choices.text: Blunting of the villi in the duodenum and proximal jejunum
Extensive colonic injury with yellow-white adherent layer
Flask-shaped ulcerations in the cecum and ascending colon
Foamy macrophages in the small intestinal lamina propria

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with abrupt-onset vomiting followed by frequent, large-volume, watery diarrhea for the last day. She has no prior medical conditions but has not received recommended vaccinations. Physical examination shows mild dehydration. The abdomen is soft and mildly tender to palpation throughout. Bowel sounds are increased. Polymerase chain reaction testing of the stool sample yields a virus with a segmented, double-stranded RNA genome. Which of the following pathologic findings is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blunting of the villi in the duodenum and proximal jejunum

 

  • Child with abrupt-onset vomiting, profuse watery diarrhea, no vaccinations → classic for rotavirus gastroenteritis.
  • Virology clue: segmented, double-stranded RNA genome = Reoviridae family → Rotavirus.
  • Pathology:
    • Rotavirus infects enterocytes of the duodenum and proximal jejunum.
    • Causes blunting of villi and loss of brush border enzymes → malabsorption and osmotic diarrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Extensive colonic injury with yellow-white adherent layer: Describes pseudomembranous colitis due to Clostridioides difficile, not rotavirus.

 

Option C. Flask-shaped ulcerations in the cecum and ascending colon: Seen in Entamoeba histolytica infection, not viral diarrhea.

 

Option D. Foamy macrophages in the small intestinal lamina propria: Pathognomonic for Whipple disease (Tropheryma whipplei), not acute viral gastroenteritis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female went on vacation and fell asleep while sitting on a beach. After some time she woke with sunburn. Later when she went back home, she experienced pain while taking a warm bath (40°C). Which of the following receptors is responsible for the pain?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Innocuous thermal receptor - allodynia

questions.text: A young athlete presented with sudden chest pain and dyspnea while playing a football match. A harsh systolic murmur is heard in the left sternal border. Which of the following will increase the murmur?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Valsalva

questions.text: Identify the given image:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Barium meal

 

The image demonstrates a classic barium meal radiograph, with opacification of the stomach and proximal duodenum, outlining the gastric contour and first part of the small intestine. The study is typically performed to assess the stomach and duodenum for ulcers, masses, or other pathology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. BMFT (Barium meal follow-through): Would include more distal small bowel (jejunum/ileum) opacification after barium passes through, not limited to stomach and duodenum.

 

Option C. Barium enteroclysis: Involves direct infusion of barium into the small intestine and demonstrates detailed small bowel loops, which are not seen here.

questions.text: Two researchers are investigating the prevalence of hypertension in a metropolitan city. The first researcher measured the blood pressure from 1032 inpatients at a tertiary care hospital in the city (study A). The second researcher performed community blood pressure screening on 1003 people (study B) through nursing health fairs. Both studies are conducted using calibrated sphygmomanometers from the same manufacturer. Compared to study A, the result of study B is most likely to have which of the following properties?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Higher accuracy

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of infertility. He does not smoke, drink, or take any medications. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Serum analysis shows anti-sperm antibodies. What is the most likely cause of this patient's serum finding?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Defect in Sertoli cell function

questions.solution: Ans. C) Hypotonia

questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to the OPD due to penile ulcers that appeared after unprotected sexual intercourse. Physical examination shows 3 subcentimeter ulcers on the penile shaft. Microscopic examination of a scraping from an ulcer base reveals the following. Which of the following medications is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acyclovir

 

  • The image shows multinucleated giant cells with ground-glass nuclei on Tzanck smear.
  • Clinical findings:
    • Painful penile ulcers appearing after unprotected sex.
    • Multiple, small ulcers with erythematous base.
  • This is classic for Genital herpes, caused by Herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2) (sometimes HSV-1).
  • Treatment of choice = Acyclovir (or valacyclovir, famciclovir).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Azithromycin:

 

  • Used for Chlamydia trachomatis infections, including nongonococcal urethritis and chancroid (Haemophilus ducreyi).
  • Not effective for HSV.

 

Option C. Fluconazole:

 

  • Used for Candida albicans infections (eg, candidal balanitis or vaginitis).
  • Candida causes erythematous patches with curdy white discharge, not ulcers.

 

Option D. Penicillin:

 

  • Used for Treponema pallidum (syphilis), which causes a painless, indurated chancre, not multiple painful ulcers.

questions.text: A chest CT scan is performed on a 35-year-old man who presented with chronic cough and weight loss. Which of the following structures labelled below is a derivative of the common cardinal veins?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

The anatomical structure labeled A in the CT scan is the superior vena cava, which is a direct derivative of the common cardinal veins during embryological development.

 

A: The right common cardinal vein and the right anterior cardinal vein unite to form the superior vena cava, an essential embryological remnant in the adult venous system.

 

B. It is the aorta (ascending/arch), derived from the embryonic truncus arteriosus and aortic arches.

 

C. It is  the pulmonary artery arch, develops from the truncus arteriosus and aortic arches, not from cardinal veins.

 

D. It is Esophagus. The esophagus develops from the anterior foregut during the early weeks of gestation.

 

E. It is Descending Aorta, continuation of Aortic Arch.

questions.text: Fibres from mamillary bodies terminate at which of the following points?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

Fibers from the mammillary bodies (mammillothalamic tract, part of the Papez circuit) terminate at the anterior nucleus of the thalamus.

 

In the illustration, A represents the anterior nucleus of the thalamus, the correct termination point for mammillary body fibers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. B→ Ventro-anterior (VA) nucleus: 

 

  • Function: Motor relay.
  • Connections: Receives input from basal ganglia (globus pallidus) → projects to premotor cortex.

 

Option C. C → Ventro-lateral (VL) nucleus:

 

  • Function: Motor relay.
  • Connections: Receives input from cerebellum & basal ganglia → projects to primary motor cortex.

 

Option D. D → Ventro-posterior lateral (VPL) nucleus:

 

  • Function: Somatosensory relay (body).

 

Connections: Receives medial lemniscus & spinothalamic tract → projects to primary somatosensory cortex.

questions.text: A rheumatologist is evaluating the long-term risk of venous thromboembolism in patients with newly diagnosed rheumatoid arthritis by comparing two retrospective cohort studies. In study A, the hazard ratio for venous thromboembolism was found to be 1.7 with a 95% confidence interval of 0.89-2.9. Study B identified a hazard ratio for venous thromboembolism of 1.6 with a 95% confidence interval of 1.1-2.5. Which of the following statements about the reported association in these studies is most accurate?
questions.solution: Ans. D) The p-value of study A is likely larger than the p-value of study B.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with a painless swelling in his right medial face since a few months. The MRI image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mucocele

 

The MRI shows a well-defined, expansile lesion in the right maxillary sinus with characteristic features of fluid retention and sinus expansion without aggressive bone destruction, consistent with a mucocele.

 

The clinical presentation of painless, progressive swelling in the medial face, along with the described MRI findings, most likely represents a Mucocele.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Maxillary sinusitis: Maxillary sinusitis typically presents with signs of infection and mucosal thickening, not expansile cystic lesions.

 

Option C. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a vascular tumor usually affecting adolescent males and arises near the nasopharynx, often with nasal obstruction and epistaxis.

 

Option D. Inverted papilloma: Inverted papilloma is a benign epithelial tumor that commonly shows unilateral nasal obstruction with papillomatous masses but does not cause expansive sinus fluid retention as seen here.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 29 weeks gestation is brought to the emergency department 1 day after the sudden onset of right upper quadrant abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. She had preeclampsia during her last pregnancy. She spent 2 weeks in Myanmar 1 month ago. She appears tired. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 182/102 mm Hg. A peripheral blood smear is shown. questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because he claims to have spoken to his recently-deceased grandfather. The boy was taken out of preschool for 3 days after his grandfather's death but has since returned. His teachers report that the boy is currently doing well, completing his assignments, and engaging in play with other children. When asked about how he feels, the boy becomes tearful and says, "I miss my grandpa. I sometimes talk to him when my mom is not around." Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
